ai-mn44:1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
ai-mn44:1.3_0: Then the layman Visākha went to the nun Dhammadinnā,
ai-mn44:1.3_1: and after approaching and worshipping the nun Dhammadinnā, he sat down on one side.
ai-mn44:1.3_2: While sitting on one side the devotee Visākha said this to the nun Dhammadinnā:
ai-mn44:2.1_0: “Ma’am, they speak of this thing called ‘identity’.
ai-mn44:2.2_0: What is this identity that the Buddha spoke of?”
ai-mn44:2.3_0: “The Buddha said that these five grasping aggregates are identity.
ai-mn44:2.4_0: That is, the grasping aggregates of form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.
ai-mn44:2.5_0: The Buddha said that these five grasping aggregates are identity.”
ai-mn44:2.6_0: Saying “Good, ma’am,” Visākha approved and agreed with what Dhammadinnā said. Then he asked another question:
ai-mn44:3.1_0: “Ma’am, they speak of this thing called ‘the origin of identity’.
ai-mn44:3.2_0: What is the origin of identity that the Buddha spoke of?”
ai-mn44:3.3_0: “It’s the craving that leads to future rebirth, mixed up with relishing and greed, taking pleasure in various different realms. That is,
ai-mn44:3.4_0: craving for sensual pleasures, craving for continued existence, and craving to end existence.
ai-mn44:3.5_0: The Buddha said that this is the origin of identity.”
ai-mn44:4.1_0: “Ma’am, they speak of this thing called ‘the cessation of identity’.
ai-mn44:4.2_0: What is the cessation of identity that the Buddha spoke of?”
ai-mn44:4.3_0: “It’s the fading away and cessation of that very same craving with nothing left over; giving it away, letting it go, releasing it, and not adhering to it.
ai-mn44:4.4_0: The Buddha said that this is the cessation of identity.”
ai-mn44:5.1_0: “Ma’am, they speak of this thing called ‘the practice that leads to the cessation of identity’.
ai-mn44:5.2_0: What is that practice that leads to the cessation of identity?”
ai-mn44:5.3_0: “The practice that leads to the cessation of identity that the Buddha spoke of is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:
ai-mn44:5.4_0: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.”
ai-mn44:6.1_0: “But ma’am, is that grasping the exact same thing as the five grasping aggregates? Or is grasping one thing and the five grasping aggregates another?”
ai-mn44:6.2_0: “That grasping is not the exact same thing as the five grasping aggregates. Nor is grasping one thing and the five grasping aggregates another.
ai-mn44:6.3_0: The desire and greed for the five grasping aggregates is the grasping there.”
ai-mn44:7.1_0: “But ma’am, how does identity view come about?”
ai-mn44:7.2_0: “It’s when an uneducated ordinary person has not seen the noble ones, and is neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve not seen good persons, and are neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the good persons.
ai-mn44:7.3_0: They regard form as self, self as having form, form in self, or self in form.
ai-mn44:7.7_0: consciousness as self, self as having consciousness, consciousness in self, or self in consciousness.
ai-mn44:7.8_0: That’s how identity view comes about.”
ai-mn44:8.1_0: “But ma’am, how does identity view not come about?”
ai-mn44:8.2_0: “It’s when an educated noble disciple has seen the noble ones, and is skilled and trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve seen good persons, and are skilled and trained in the teaching of the good persons.
ai-mn44:8.3_0: They don’t regard form as self, self as having form, form in self, or self in form.
ai-mn44:8.6_0: They don’t regard choices as self ...
ai-mn44:8.7_0: consciousness as self, self as having consciousness, consciousness in self, or self in consciousness.
ai-mn44:8.8_0: That’s how identity view does not come about.”
ai-mn44:9.1_0: “But ma’am, what is the noble eightfold path?”
ai-mn44:9.2_0: “It is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:
ai-mn44:9.3_0: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.”
ai-mn44:10.1_0: “But ma’am, is the noble eightfold path conditioned or unconditioned?”
ai-mn44:11.1_0: “Are the three practice categories included in the noble eightfold path? Or is the noble eightfold path included in the three practice categories?”
ai-mn44:11.2_0: “The three practice categories are not included in the noble eightfold path.
ai-mn44:11.2_1: The noble eightfold path is included in the three practice categories.
ai-mn44:11.3_0: Right speech, right action, and right livelihood: these things are included in the category of ethics.
ai-mn44:11.4_0: Right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion: these things are included in the category of immersion.
ai-mn44:11.5_0: Right view and right thought: these things are included in the category of wisdom.”
ai-mn44:12.1_0: “But ma’am, what is immersion? What things are the foundations of immersion? What things are the prerequisites for immersion? What is the development of immersion?”
ai-mn44:12.3_0: The four kinds of mindfulness meditation are the foundations of immersion.
ai-mn44:12.4_0: The four right efforts are the prerequisites for immersion.
ai-mn44:12.5_0: The cultivation, development, and making much of these very same things is the development of immersion.”
ai-mn44:14.1_0: “But ma’am, what is the physical process? What’s the verbal process? What’s the mental process?”
ai-mn44:14.2_0: “Breathing is a physical process. Placing the mind and keeping it connected are verbal processes. Perception and feeling are mental processes.”
ai-mn44:15.1_0: “But ma’am, why is breathing a physical process? Why are placing the mind and keeping it connected verbal processes? Why are perception and feeling mental processes?”
ai-mn44:15.2_0: “Breathing is physical process. These things are a body’s motion. That’s why breathing is a physical process.
ai-mn44:15.3_0: First you place the mind and keep it connected, then you break into speech. That’s why placing the mind and keeping it connected are verbal processes.
ai-mn44:15.4_0: Perception and feeling are mental factors, these things are bound up with the mind, that is why perception and feeling are mental processes.”
ai-mn44:16.1_0: “But ma’am, how does someone attain the cessation of perception and feeling?”
ai-mn44:16.2_0: “A mendicant who is entering such an attainment does not think:
ai-mn44:16.3_0: ‘I will enter the cessation of perception and feeling’ or ‘I am entering the cessation of perception and feeling’ or ‘I have entered the cessation of perception and feeling.’
ai-mn44:16.4_0: Rather, their mind has been previously developed so as to lead to such a state.”
ai-mn44:17.1_0: “But ma’am, which cease first for a mendicant who is entering the cessation of perception and feeling: physical, verbal, or mental processes?”
ai-mn44:17.2_0: “Verbal processes cease first, then physical, then mental.”
ai-mn44:18.1_0: “But ma’am, how does someone emerge from the cessation of perception and feeling?”
ai-mn44:18.2_0: “A mendicant who is emerging from such an attainment does not think:
ai-mn44:18.3_0: ‘I will emerge from the cessation of perception and feeling’ or ‘I am emerging from the cessation of perception and feeling’ or ‘I have emerged from the cessation of perception and feeling.’
ai-mn44:18.4_0: Rather, their mind has been previously developed so as to lead to such a state.”
ai-mn44:19.1_0: “But ma’am, which arise first for a mendicant who is emerging from the cessation of perception and feeling: physical, verbal, or mental processes?”
ai-mn44:19.2_0: “Mental processes arise first, then physical, then verbal.”
ai-mn44:20.1_0: “But ma’am, when a mendicant has emerged from the attainment of the cessation of perception and feeling, how many kinds of contact do they experience?”
ai-mn44:20.2_0: “They experience three kinds of contact: emptiness, signless, and undirected contacts.”
ai-mn44:21.1_0: “What is the culmination of the cessation of perception and feeling?”
ai-mn44:21.2_0: “Their mind slants, slopes, and inclines to seclusion.”
ai-mn44:22.1_0: “But ma’am, how many feelings are there?”
ai-mn44:23.2_0: “Anything felt physically or mentally as pleasant or enjoyable.
ai-mn44:23.4_0: Anything felt physically or mentally as painful or unpleasant.
ai-mn44:23.6_0: Anything felt physically or mentally as neither pleasurable nor painful.
ai-mn44:24.1_0: “What is pleasant and what is painful in each of the three feelings?”
ai-mn44:24.2_0: “Pleasant feeling, friend Visākha, is pleasant when it persists, unpleasant when it changes,
ai-mn44:24.3_0: Painful feeling is painful when it remains and pleasant when it perishes.
ai-mn44:24.4_0: Neutral feeling is pleasant when there is knowledge, and painful when there is ignorance.”
ai-mn44:25.1_0: “What underlying tendencies underlie each of the three feelings?”
ai-mn44:25.2_0: “The underlying tendency for greed underlies pleasant feeling. The underlying tendency for repulsion underlies painful feeling. The underlying tendency for ignorance underlies neutral feeling.”
ai-mn44:26.1_0: “Do these underlying tendencies always underlie these feelings?”
ai-mn44:27.1_0: “What should be given up in regard to each of these three feelings?”
ai-mn44:27.2_0: “The underlying tendency to greed should be given up when it comes to pleasant feeling. The underlying tendency to repulsion should be given up when it comes to painful feeling. The underlying tendency to ignorance should be given up when it comes to neutral feeling.”
ai-mn44:28.1_0: “Should these underlying tendencies be given up regarding all instances of these feelings?”
ai-mn44:28.3_0: Take a mendicant who, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
ai-mn44:28.4_0: With this they give up greed, and the underlying tendency to greed does not lie within that.
ai-mn44:28.5_0: And take a mendicant who reflects:
ai-mn44:28.6_0: ‘Oh, when will I enter and remain in the same dimension that the noble ones enter and remain in today?’
ai-mn44:28.7_0: Nursing such a longing for the supreme liberations gives rise to sadness due to longing.
ai-mn44:28.8_0: On that basis repulsion is abandoned, and herein there is no more underlying tendency to repulsion.
ai-mn44:28.9_0: Take a mendicant who, giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, enters and remains in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.
ai-mn44:28.10_0: With this they give up ignorance, and the underlying tendency to ignorance does not lie within that.”
ai-mn44:29.1_0: “But ma’am, what is the counterpart of pleasant feeling?”
ai-mn44:29.3_0: “But ma’am, what is the counterpart of neutral feeling?”
ai-mn44:29.5_0: “What is the counterpart of neutral feeling?”
ai-mn44:29.13_0: “But ma’am, what is the counterpart of extinguishment?”
ai-mn44:29.14_0: “Your question goes too far, Visākha. You couldn’t figure out the limit of questions.
ai-mn44:29.15_0: For extinguishment is the culmination, destination, and end of the spiritual life.
ai-mn44:29.16_0: If you wish, go to the Buddha and ask him this question. You should remember it in line with his answer.”
ai-mn44:30.1_0: And then the layman Visākha approved and agreed with what the nun Dhammadinnā said. He got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled her, keeping her on his right. Then he went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side,
ai-mn44:30.2_0: and informed the Buddha of all they had discussed.
ai-mn44:30.3_0: That being said, the Fortunate One said this to the devotee Visākha:
ai-mn44:30.4_0: “The nun Visākha, Vekha, is the nun Dhammadinnā, of Dhammadinnā,
ai-mn44:30.5_0: If you came to me and asked this question, I would answer it in exactly the same way as the nun Dhammadinnā.
ai-mn44:30.6_0: That is what it means, and that’s how you should remember it.”
ai-mn44:30.7_0: That is what the Buddha said.
ai-mn44:30.8_0: Satisfied, the layman Visākha was happy with what the Buddha said.
ai-mn44:30.9_0: The fourth section on the Shorter Discourse is finished.
